qas.question: Who wins in a wrestling match?

answers.text: the first side to achieve the majority number of pinfalls, submissions, or countouts being the winner.

qas.question: How could a wrestler win in the past?

answers.text: Historically, matches were wrestled to 3 falls ("best 2 out of 3") or 5 falls ("best 3 out of 5").

qas.question: How can a wrestler win in modern times?

answers.text: The standard for modern matches is one fall.

qas.question: In what instance will a match be declared a draw?

answers.text: if not enough falls are scored by the end of the time limit, the match is declared a draw.

qas.question: How long can a title match be?

answers.text: title matches can go for up to one hour

context: Most wrestling matches last for a set number of falls, with <a0_0>the first side to achieve the majority number of pinfalls, submissions, or countouts being the winner.<a0_0/> <a1_0>Historically, matches were wrestled to 3 falls ("best 2 out of 3") or 5 falls ("best 3 out of 5").<a1_0/> <a2_0>The standard for modern matches is one fall.<a2_0/> However, even though it is now standard, many announcers will explicitly state this (e.g. "The following contest is set for one fall with a 20-minute time limit"). These matches are given a time limit; <a3_0>if not enough falls are scored by the end of the time limit, the match is declared a draw.<a3_0/> Modern matches are generally given a 10- to 30-minute time limit for standard matches; <a4_0>title matches can go for up to one hour<a4_0/>. British wrestling matches held under Admiral-Lord Mountevans rules are 2 out of 3 falls.
